ratings.comment: Prof. Dykman's Abnormal Psych class was definitely very difficult, but also very doable. Use the readings as reinforcements of the lectures, and don't be afraid to send him emails to clarify any confusion between the two. (he is good about sending emails to clarify content--if brought to his attention) The curve will help your grades in the end!

Dykman is clear, interesting, knowledgable, respectful of students and very nice to students. Very smart, knows a lot about a lot. His liking of psychology is contagious to the class. I'm more likely to be a psych major now. He'll inspire you. All round great teacher. HOT smarts and hot bod.

Although abnormal psychology sounds super interesting, Dykman sucks the life right out of it. I enjoyed reading the book more than going to lecture; but you have to do both to pass. Thankfully, he drops one exam score.

The lectures are very dry. His test are based off of the lecture and the book, but he tends to contradict the book in his lectures. Test questions are very specific. For an intro level psych class he focuses more on small details than the big picture when it comes to the test.

I worked my butt off to get the grade I did and would not take this class with him again. He rarely acknowledged students with their hands raised. Lectures were dry, he doesn't do a lot to engage students. Tests are rote memorization but detail-heavy and require A LOT of studying to do well. Nice & knowledgeable? Yes. But he's not a good teacher

Dykman is an extremely knowledgable professor and an all around great guy. He cares about his students and really wants them to excel in his class, and his age adds a sometimes unintended, quirky humor to his lectures, which is a bonus. If you reciprocate his interest in the course, do the reading, and attend lectures, his exams are pretty trivial.

Professor Dykman is the best professor I had the pleasure of learning from, and Abnormal Psychology is the best course I have taken in college. His lectures  convey a lot of information, which can at times leave you scrambling to get everything down. His jokes are golden. Video clips give you an idea of what treatment is like. Read chapters twice.

Go to lecture and take good notes. Also take good notes on the book chapters.  You'll need them for the tests, which are kind of nit picky but still doable. Study for tests at least 2 days in advance. Take extra credit chance. Professor has his funny moments and has ways to help ease the studying. A little effort goes a long way in this class.

Class is based solely off of 4 exams (but there is extra credit opportunity). His lectures are boring. Exams are 50% lecture/50% textbook, but lean more on the textbook, so make sure you read. Pretty nice guy, just boring. Makes a lot of stupid funny accidental jokes & goes on a lot of tangents. He tries to be helpful. Get a diff prof if you can.
Boring lectures. Impossible midterms. Worst class I've taken. Avoid Dykman at all costs.

Although Professor Dykman's exams are pretty tricky, I think that the class itself is enjoyable. His lectures are always entertaining and interesting, even showing videos so that we get a good idea of the material; however, the amount of reading is a lot with other classes and the exams are 50% lecture and 50% book. Makes you work for it for sure.

I would have benefited much from a discussion class, but alas. Psych is the worst class I've taken so far, due to the heavy textbook readings that are hardly covered in class. While Dykman's lectures are far from bad, his tests are horrid, as 70% of the questions are based from textbook readings. And be prepared to do extra credit. you'll need it.
Dykman is easily the worst intro psych teacher. His lectures are fine, but the tests and questions are way too hard. Definitely avoid having him if you can.
good professor, really funny. I definitely learned a lot from his lectures! Do not miss a single lecture... he covers a lot of stuff that isnt mentioned in the required readings.

Do not take this class.  He claims half of the questions are from the reading and half are from the lecture. Get ready to memorize every word of the textbook, as most of the questions use specific percentages etc. Lectures make no sense even if you have already read the textbook 3 times. Beware!!

He's a really nice guy, but his syllabus says that the book is the only thing that will be tested on, when at least 40% of the exam questions are straight from lecture. There's no HW, so there's no real opportunity to boost your grade. Be prepared to memorize the textbook and lecture notes due to very detailed exam questions.

Cog behavior therapy w Dykman is the best clinical course you will ever take, maybe better than what you'll receive in grad school. He's very smart, clinically insightful, and caring. The course covers everything you need to know to be a truly  effective clinical psychologist--a true scientist practitioner. Well taught

knows the subject matter inside out, very smart, very knowledgable. He's a very caring person, very responsive to students. you feel you really know the material when the course is over. if you put in the work you'll be rewarded. the best course I've ever taken.

he's a really nice guy, super smart, very clear, very interesting, tries to help his students  do well.  supplements lecture with visual materials in an interesting way that helps you remember it better and want to come to class. super

I had heard many negative things about professor Dykman going into this class. Despite this, I really enjoyed my experience with him. If you put in effort and are willing to learn, you will do well. He loves what he does and cares that his students understand the material. Dykman is a good choice for PSY 509.

I feel that this class & Dykman get a bad rep. but if you are a good student and go to class, take GOOD notes, and actually start to study about a week before the exam rather than cram the night before it is totally do-able. Dykman is awkward in a hilarious sort of way and a professor I'll miss!  One of my favorite classes, but requires hard work.

His lectures are boring, but you have to go no matter what otherwise you won't pass. Also you have to read the textbook, and not just skimming but actually taking notes on the readings because 50% of exam material comes from the book. Don't take this class if you don't have to... It's definitely not worth it.

Professor Dykman enjoys what he does. Lectures can get long, but the material is useful. That being said, the exams are mostly on the book readings (3 chapters per exam, no cumulative final) but he tends to sneak in a few questions from lecture that you have to pay attention to answer correctly. This class was tough, but a decent intro class.

Try to avoid dykman, as he talks really slowly and half the tests are about material covered only in the book. So you have to read the whole thing to pass. That said, if you show up to class and read, the tests are easy. He gives a ton of extra credit, and there is no homework.
Taking Intro Psych with Dykman is a great experience. Super clear, helpful, smart, fair. Superb in all respects. Keep up with the readings.

Dykman is organized, clear, illustrates everything with graphs or video, goes at the right pace, occasionally funny, super smart yet can relate to you on a personal level with everyday language, treats students super well, goes out of his way to be fair and understanding . I'm going to take every course I can with him.
He is the most boring, disorganized, and unhelpful professor I have ever had.

Dykman will test you. The guy is a genius and good at what he does, but if you aren't a psych major you should definitely find someone else. His tests are 50% book, most of which IS NOT COVERED IN CLASS. Dykman loves to be tricky and will put questions that are going to make you think on his exams. I studied around 15 hours for each one.
No homework, curved tests, gives extra credit, funny guy

He's good at what he does, but can be a bit insensitive in lecture. Exam questions are oddly specific; the kind of questions that are meant to trick you. Interesting course, but be ready to work if you want a good grade.

Attending class and skimming the book will ensure you an AB. Dykman is endearing and comical. If you get easily frustrated by tough tests,  it's time to learn to let it go. The curve will help you in the end. You'll learn a lot, but again, the tests might not make you feel that way.
Dykman is interesting, clear, knowledgeable,  inspiring, smart, fair, a very nice person. Great course taught by a great guy. he makes interesting material even more interesting. Not to be missed.
This is a great class taught by a knowledgeable, nice, clear, and very fair professor. His tests are fair. You just need to study (as if you were in college). I totally enjoyed this class.

BEWARE! This guy does not like you if you're not a psych major. He thinks you should put in 40 hours into studying for each exam. In my opinion, he simply can not teach. He can't articulate the things that are important. This guy is definitely one of the worst professors I've had at UW. I went to class, did the reading, and that wasn't enough.

Lectures are super important if you want to do well on the exams. Reading is also super important for doing well. Exams: 75 multiple choice based on lecture and textbook. Write down everything he says, even minor details, because there's a good chance it'll be on the exam.  Generous curve, but lectures are unorganizeddifficult to follow.

The class content is fascinating, but his teaching style makes it hard to understand well.. slow and unclear at times. I studied for all the tests and went to lectures, but ended up doing worse than I expected on exams.  He usually drops the lowest midterm grade, though.

Methodically dissects psychological disorders in lecture. Write down everything he says, memorize diagnostic criteria for each disorder, know what differentiates similar disorders, and read book chapters twice before exams. Tedious, but will get you an A. He also adopted much more generous grading curve this semester - top 20% got As.

Most confusing and hard class I've taken so far. He's not very helpful and just overall disorganized and unclear. Hard tests! Be ready to read, the textbook is essential. I really wish I could have taken this class with a different professor because it is something I'm very interested in.

Some of the questions were specific things that he said once during lecture, however I would take this class again for sure. The lectures were very interesting, however the exams are half from lecture and half from the books. This class takes a lot of time, however if you are interested in psychology then it is worth it! I loved this class!

Incredibly interesting material, Dykman definitely knows his stuff, easy to see that he is passionate about what he does. The tests were challenging enough for this level but questions about mundane book details and specific percentages frustrated me greatly. Ran videos past class which is irritating. Overall, not bad but requires great effort

Very interesting material, but I regret taking it with Dykman. Tests on the captions of pictures in the textbook, words questions ambiguously on exams, and expects you to memorize the textbook basically. Wouldn't recommend taking with a heavy course load because you'll be spending all your time on this class.

Luckily the grading procedure has changed in favor of the students recently! However, tests are tough. Half the material is from lecture, and half is from the textbook. YOU MUST READ THE BOOK TO PASS. Overall the class was fine.
You have to read the book to pass.

He's a sweet old guy that will give you the help IF you ask for it. I went in to see him after I failed the first test (luckily, you can drop one) and he spent 45 mins having me read a paragraph from the book and answer questions bout it. He really cares but you need to pay attention IN CLASS and TO DETAIL IN BOOK. exams are 12 lecture 12 book.

Dykman is with it. Is helpful, clear, exciting, often funny. Great audio visuals that make the course come alive. An easy grader if you bother to student. The curve he uses favors students. The only students I know who don't like him are students who are expecting an easy ride and don't bother to study, or take notes, or come to class. GREAT CLASS

Dykman is a complete professor. Very smart, very clear lectures, gives lectures  that are interesting. Just study like your supposed to. He's a very nice person, he'll  gladly explain anything you don't understand. He has a lot of wisdom. He really makes you think. He's mind-expanding. I'm going to take as many courses with him as I can.

I took professor Dykman for abnormal psych. His lectures are unclear and tests are full of questions pertaining to the smallest details. Many of the things he says could be taken very offensively to somebody with mental disorders. He makes a lot of unnecessary generalizations about people with mental disorders. Disrespectful .
Ridiculous test questions. Why even bother studying if every single question is completely obscure and meant to trick you?
just memorize the textbook. thats it. Dont expect to learn sth interesting. try to memorize all the details from the lectures and textbook
very intelligent, interesting, fair. Great course, great guy

Starting this semester (Fall 2014) for psych 202  he made his class way easier: 1) 33% get A's or AB's 2) 15 points of extra credit will bump you up one letter grade 3) He drops your lowest midterm  Honestly his class wasn't bad at all. Read the textbook and learn EVERY detail. Study the experiments he talks about in lecture. Good luck.

Help is there if you need it but if you like most freshman students find yourself having a hard time finding freetime this class can be a struggle. Definitely recommend joining a BLC or something like that because you will not get above a C in the class without it, wish I would have. Also, tests are VERY difficult.

This is a complete CBT therapy course taught by a complete professor. You'll really know how to do cog beh therapy after taking this course, and it'll help you get into graduate school. It looks good on your vita and it's good to say you took it. Dykman is smart, both clinically and scientifically. You'll really learn how to conceptualize and treat
Slow lectures and gives a good outline to follow and fill in. Matches other professors perks. Not the best for help but he explains things descent in lecture.
Great guy, interesting lectures, really difficult tests.
terrible, exam questions are random and very difficult for an intro to psych class. would avoid him like the plague

Dykman is a really good guy; he's nice, respectful, and considerate, I think. Sure, there might be a lot of memorizing or detailed textbook reading, but it's interesting material. Really excited to see that he's teaching 509 next semester!!

Be prepared to study hard for the tests. There are four tests so it's easy to improve if you don't do well right away. Use the study guide you can buy for the book. He asks about obscure details from lectures & textbook on tests. Expect to attend lectures even though not mandatory, that material will be on the test. Do the extra credit quiz!!

Dykman is an ok professor, the lectures were fun mostly because of his videos. His exams are frustrating because you basically have to read and memorize every detail/picture caption/word of each of the ~40 page book chapters.I would not recommend him, unless you are desperate.Exams are only graded content and are really frustrating.DO EXTRA CREDIT!

I really liked Intro with Dykman, it inspired me to take additional classes in Psych, esp those taught by Dykman. The man is really smart, knows a lot, and really likes psychology. If you ask him a question he's responsive and interested in what you have to say. Very reinforcing, very nice. Uses the same curve as the other Intro Psych profs use.

Dykman got applause on the last day of class, and for good reason. He really knows how to make the lectures interesting and enjoyable. Classes whiz by, 75 minutes seem like 30 minutes. He's sincere and helpful. He finds your comments interesting, and builds on them. The material in this class is stuff you'll put to use in life. Great class & prof.

Dykman is passionate about psych and knows his stuff for the most part, always willing to help. honestly, tests aren't THAT bad just take detailed class notes and take notes when reading the book. Tests ask nit picky questions but if you study a decent amount and take GOOD notes you should be absolutely fine

Professor Dykman is the sweetest and funniest man! He is so knowledgable about everything abnormal psychology related, and his lectures are packed with valuable information. My favorite class so far at UW! Exams are tough, but do-able. DEFINITELY attend lecture, take really detailed notes, and read the book a couple times, and you should be golden!

I'm a senior and Ab Psych with Dykman the best course I ever took at UW. If I wasnt' graduating I'd start a Dykman fan club. He's absolutely terrific and so too is his class. Super smart, super helpful super guy. He's a true expert teacher. Love him.

Dykman is an all-round great professor. Smart, clear, helpful, interesting. People knock him because of exams. They forget the same curve applies to all classes. If you got an F in his class you'd get an F in another Intro class. I highly recommend Intro with Dykman. Super class with super man. I'm going to take all his classes. Great attitude too.
Horrible. Exams unnecessarily challenging.

Dykman's exams involve virtually no critical thinking. Basically to do well in this class you will need to memorize the entire chapters of the textbook cos a question on any random detail is fair game. Attend all the lectures too

He goes on tangents for a majority of the class and they never have anything to do with the material. His tests are also based 50% on the book and in order to get the book questions correct you need to memorize the textbook
He is the cutest old man ever. His pic on learn@UW with his dog is amazing! If you have him have fun reading each chapter at least 3 times. I mean thats what you have to do to get an A.

Dykman is really nice. Always tries to be helpful. Gives interesting lectures. Funny too. Super smart. Inspirational. Great class. I'm going to take Cognitive Therapy with Dykman as well. He's really super nice. Wants to be helpful. Explains things really well. Will stay after class to explain things. Great guy, great class! You'll learn a lot.

Dykman is a super nice guy inside and outside of class. Gives great, enthusiastic, interesting lectures. Sometimes funny too. You can tell the guy is real smart and really knows his stuff. Exams are fine if you study the way you're supposed to. This is a great class. I'm going to take Abn Psych with Dykman too. He's really helpful, sincere. Great!

Although he seems like a nice guy in class, talking to him outside of class is not a similar experience. He does not see your point of view on things and often does not give you the light of day when you question his exam questions (which he writes the night before the exam). If you're stuck with him, GO TO CLASS, but really try avoiding him.

He can be a bit behind with the lecture outlines, but he is passionate and makes lectures fun and enjoyable to attend, even though not mandatory. Should attend though, exams are about 40% lecture, and 60% book, so missing a lecture only hurts yourself.

He is very nice but spacey and his exams were super hard! Most of the questions were things we never even went over in lecture because you are supposed to read the chapters on your own. You might as well read the chapters in your own time and skip lecture.

Do not listen to the comments on how good Dykman is, he is one of the worst professors I have ever had to endure for a semester. Poor speaker, drags on for what seems like forever, half his exam questions are from the examples in the margin of the textbook. DO NOT TAKE DYKMAN FOR PSYCH 202!

Dykman is very knowledgeable on this subject and the class is super interesting. Attendance isn't mandatory but you will want to go, he shows a lot of really interesting videos. The exams are picky but if you are reading this you already have an advantage because you know you need to put just a wee bit more time into this class WORTH IT THOUGH

Dykman is great in all respects. clear, organized, interesting, helpful, a nice man. This is an interesting class taught by an interesting, enthusiastic professor. The lower the class mean on exams, the easier the curve, so difficulty is not a problem. All round great class. Important to take for understanding today's world.

Professor Dykman was unclear on what he wanted for exams and did not ask about what he claimed was important in class. No study guides. Not much help in person either. I had really wanted to take this class and was excited about it until I took some of his exams as they did not reflect material presented in class. Do not recommend.

Interesting subject and Dykman seems to care about the class. That being said, the videos and examples he uses are outdated, he tests on extreme specifics from the textbook which was frustrating, and there was a tough curve as in all psych classes. If I could go back, I would take the class again but with any other teacher.

This class is not impossible, but it is indeed difficult.  My test grades were a B, C, AB, A, so you really have to study (I made flashcards, which helped alot). READ THE TEXTBOOK.  Some of the questions have to do with statistics or lecture notes not lining up with book notes.  All psych profs use the same curve, so can't complain about that.

Dykman is superb in all respects. clear, organized, interesting lectures.hot!Don't expect to be spoon fed. You gotta study like you were really in college. Harder exams only mean an easier curve, If you don't do well in this class, you wouldn't do well in other classes. All psych profs use the same ridiculous weeding out curve.Great prof& class!

If you have the option of taking Psych 202 with another professor I highly suggest you do that. Dykman is really passionate, loves psych, but teaching is NOT his thing. His lecture notes aren't very clear, he's hard to follow. His tests are 80% book material he doesn't cover. 80%!! In other words, you have to read every single page. Happy I'm done.

Although he was very passionate about the subject, the organization of the lectures was iffy at best.  A lot of time the information he gave was inconsistent with the facts presented in the textbook used, and explanations of some topics were really unclear.  The exams are somewhat nitpick on minor facts, but they're doable if you read carefully.

Dykman is a great professor and a very nice person. He personifies intellectual and physical health--the only guy who could get a knee replacement and not miss a single class--in better shape than any other professor I know. He's clear, interesting, enthusiastic. I'm going to major in psychology because I took this class with him. He's inspiring!
He is boring and old. He speaks slowly and stutters and mumbles. He should probably retire soon.

Stimulating lectures, stimulating video clips to illustrate concepts, clear and easy to follow explanations. All round nice guy. Helpful attitude. Follows the same weeding out curve as the other Intro profs. I enjoy this class.

It doesn't matter how hard or easy the exam is. 35% always get either an A, AB, or B. The problem is the Psych dept's weeding out curve. Dykman is great! Older studies are sometimes mentioned because they are classics. I'm glad I'm taking Intro Psych with Dykman

He was by far the worst professor that I have ever had. He was no help in class and his exams didn't test you on your knowledge of psychology but rather on how well you can memorize random and pointless studies found in the book.

The entire lecture portion of this class is ridiculous. Dykman presents material in an attempts to shock the class by what research has shown. This is all well and good, and would have been a fascinating approach, except all of his data seems to come from the early to mid 90's. I lost track of how many times he said, "I wish I had more recent data"

Very interesting class, Dykman is actually a very entertaining and dedicated professor. On the flip side, yes you literally have to memorize entire chapters for exams. And the exams have zero gimme questions. Every question makes you think.

Dykman is imtellectually, pedagogically, interpersonally, physically awesome. It's a great class with a great instructor. Dykman's a great all-round guy. It's the psych department and their weeding-out curve that's the problem--that applies to all the Intro Psych classes equally.

Challenging, but by no means impossible. Averaged a 94% on exams with only moderately more preparation than other classes (plus there's up to 5% extra credit available!). Arbitrarily nitpicky questions on exams were the exception, not the norm, but they did exist. Most questions were challenging in a fair and meaningful way.

DO NOT go into the class thinking its impossible because its not if you take the time to read the book. He is very clear during lecture and you aren't overwhelmed with note taking which is nice. He does test on details, but they aren't meaningless and if you read the book then you should know those details.
Absolutely awful - take this class with a different professor. He is incredibly hard to understand and his tests never ask about the key points of what was covered in the book or lecture.

Honestly, this class and prof get a bad rap. If you study diligently, take good notes, and read/note the book, the class isn't bad. I went from a BC on the first test to A and AB on the next two (plus 19/20 on the Extra Credit quiz) just by improving my studying methods. Don't be afraid of this class! Work hard and you'll be fine!

His powerpoints that he provides in class are basically worthless,he doesn't put them online and rambles a lot during lecture. You basically need to memorize the book. Find a different prof at all costs, friends i talked to all had much better profs. As a positive he shows lots of video clips that are interesting.
exams are impossible. A LOT of details required. interesting materials but extremely hard to study for.
Easy class, not time consuming. just go to lecture and read the book the day before or day of the test and its an easy A

Professor Dykman is an awesome teacher.  His class is fun and interesting, and he is fair.  He is super nice and just wants to be respected-show respect, he will like you. You have to read the book, and if you don't you will fail.  Same for attending class. He curves AND gives a 15 pt EC quiz, so if you can't get a good grade, it is your own fault.

Good professor and helpful.  Just keep in mind. He test EVERYTHING in the BOOK and Lecture outline! Don't think he would not test some strange or tiny thing.if you want to get an A. It's the same for you to take any psychology class. But it is a really interesting class and maybe the most interesting class I've ever took in the college.
